newsitem.title: JORDAN: Jordan delays 150,000 T wheat tender to Oct 17.
newsitem.headline: Jordan delays 150,000 T wheat tender to Oct 17.

text.p: Jordan has postponed a snap tender to buy 150,000 tonnes of U.S. red hard winter or spring wheat or equivalent origin to October 17 due to a U.S. holiday, traders said on Monday.
Jordan originally set October 15 as a deadline for bids, but postponed it due to the U.S. Columbus Day holiday, traders said.

An annex to the tender announced on Monday said that offers for U.S. origin wheat are to be covered under a $40 million credit guarantee for gain purchases granted to Jordan last September to be made available under the GSM-102 programme.
The shipment is to be delivered in three lots of 50,000 tonnes each in November, December and January.
Officials said the government may lower bread prices in Jordan if offer levels are attractive enough.
Jordan is considering a reduction in bread prices prompted by recent cheaper wheat purchases.
The decision to almost double bread prices in August in line with IMF-agreed economic reforms led to the worst civil unrest since riots in 1989, also sparked by government price rises.
Since August Jordan has bought 140,000 tonnes of wheat at prices ranging from $191-206 per tonne, a drop of nearly 25 percent from a high of $275 per tonne in May.
Bread is a staple food for Jordan's 4.2 million people, who have a per capita gross domestic product of about $1,500 a year.
